Article.Abstract: T cells generally recognize peptide antigens bound to MHC proteins through contacts with residues found within or immediately flanking the seven- to nine-residue sequence accommodated in the MHC peptide-binding groove. However, some T cells require peptide residues outside this region for activation, the structural basis for which is unknown. Here, we have investigated a HIV Gag-specific T cell clone that requires an unusually long peptide antigen for activation. The crystal structure of a minimally antigenic 16-mer bound to HLA-DR1 shows that the peptide C-terminal region bends sharply into a hairpin turn as it exits the binding site, orienting peptide residues outside the MHC-binding region in position to interact with a T cell receptor. Peptide truncation and substitution studies show that both the hairpin turn and the extreme C-terminal residues are required for T cell activation. These results demonstrate a previously unrecognized mode of MHC-peptide-T cell receptor interaction.
Article.ArticleTitle: A hairpin turn in a class II MHC-bound peptide orients residues outside the binding groove for T cell recognition.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: HIV Core Protein p24;HLA-DR1 Antigen;Peptide Fragments
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Antigen Presentation; Binding Sites; Crystallization; HIV Core Protein p24(chemistry); HLA-DR1 Antigen(metabolism); Humans; Lymphocyte Activation; Molecular Sequence Data; Peptide Fragments(chemistry); Protein Conformation; T-Lymphocytes(immunology)

Journal.Title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Journal.MedlineTa: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: The CD4+ T cell clone AC-25 was isolated from an individual acutely infected with HIV-1. PBMC were restimulated in vitro with Gag (p24) protein and cloned by limiting dilution.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope was the minimal peptide recognized by T cell clone AC-25, in an analysis of truncations of 22-mer peptide AFSPEVIPMFSALSEGATPQDL. The truncated 13-mer peptide PEVIPMFSALSEG binds to HLA-DR1, but does not activate AC-25.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: The CD4+ T cell clone AC-25 was isolated from an individual acutely infected with HIV-1. PBMC were restimulated in vitro with Gag (p24) protein and cloned by limiting dilution.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope was recognized by T cell clone AC-25. Alanine scanning of the epitope showed that residues E2, I4, F7 and T15 were critical for T cell recognition. Substitution G13P abolished a reverse turn in the peptide structure and abrogated T cell activation.

The crystal structure of the epitope in complex with HLA-DR1 was determined by molecular replacement. The epitope/MHC complex was crystallized in the presence of superantigen, SEC3-3B2, a variant of a staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin.

The crystal structure of the epitope in complex with HLA-DR1 was determined by molecular replacement. The epitope/MHC complex was crystallized in the presence of superantigen, SEC3-3B2, a variant of a staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin.
